definitions.definition: very, extremely, or to such a degree:
used before a noun or before "not" to emphasize what is being said:
examples: Don't wear that - it's so last year (= it was fashionable last year but not now).

definitions.definition: used at the end of a sentence to mean to a very great degree:
examples: Is that why you hate him so?

definitions.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to connect it with something that has been said or has happened previously:
examples: So, there I was standing at the edge of the road with only my underwear on ...

definitions.definition: used as a way of making certain that you or someone else understand something correctly, often when you are repeating the important points of a plan:
examples: So we leave on the Thursday and get back the next Tuesday, is that right?

definitions.definition: used to refer to a discovery that you have just made:
examples: So that's what he does when I'm not around!

definitions.definition: used as a short pause, sometimes to emphasize what you are saying:
examples: So, here we are again - just you and me.

definitions.definition: used before you introduce a subject of conversation that is of present interest, especially when you are asking a question:
examples: So, who do you think is going to win the election?

definitions.definition: used to show that you agree with something that someone has just said, but you do not think that it is important:
examples: So the car's expensive - well, I can afford it.

definitions.definition: used before you give an explanation for the action that you have just mentioned:
examples: [ + (that) ] I deliberately didn't have lunch so (that) I would be hungry tonight.
I always keep fruit in the fridge so as to keep flies off it.
He did not switch on the light so as not to disturb her.
